name: Big Trees Loop - Anatomy of a Giant
description: This interpretive loop trail leads hikers through a grove of massive, ancient trees to explore the biological factors that contribute to their immense size and longevity.

images.title: Big Trees - Anatomy of a Giant (Stop 2)
images.altText: Boardwalk in Mariposa Grove with sequoia trees
images.caption: Big Trees Loop - Anatomy of a Giant (Stop 2)

raw_listing_description: These massive trees grow bigger and live longer than almost any other living things on earth. Which of the following factors do you think is most important to their longevity?
raw_body_text: Anatomy of a Giant These massive trees grow bigger and live longer than almost any other living things on earth. Which of the following factors do you think is most important to their longevity?

name: Big Trees Loop - Grove Restoration
description: This loop trail travels through a giant sequoia grove that was once paved, highlighting restoration efforts to return the area to its natural state.

images.title: Big Trees - Grove Restoration (Stop 8)
images.altText: Flat sequoia round and exhibit in foreground, fence, and sequoias and other trees in background
images.caption: Big Trees Loop - Grove Restoration (Stop 8)

raw_listing_description: The ground you stand on was once asphalt, which did not give falling sequoia seeds a chance to germinate. Read about recent efforts to restore this area back to a place where giant sequoias can thrive.
raw_body_text: Grove Restoration The ground you stand on was once asphalt, which did not give falling sequoia seeds a chance to germinate. Read about recent efforts to restore this area back to a place where giant sequoias can thrive.

name: Big Trees Loop - How Giants Fall
description: This interpretive loop trail winds through giant sequoias, focusing on the lifecycle of these ancient trees and the natural factors that lead to their eventual fall.

images.title: Big Trees - How Giants Fall (Stop 7)
images.altText: Dead and fallen sequoia on the ground near a boardwalk
images.caption: Big Trees Loop - How Giants Fall (Stop 7)

raw_listing_description: Giant sequoias can survive for thousands of years, but they are not invincible. What conditions threaten a giant sequoias survival?
raw_body_text: How Giants Fall Giant sequoias can survive for thousands of years, but they are not invincible. What conditions threaten a giant sequoias survival?

name: Big Trees Loop - Restore and Protect
description: Wander through a grove of majestic giant sequoias in Mariposa Grove, a sanctuary first protected for public recreation in 1864.

images.title: Big Trees - Restore & Protect (Stop 12)
images.altText: Wayside exhibit along a fence with sequoias in background
images.caption: Big Trees Loop - Restore and Protect (Stop 12)

raw_listing_description: In 1864 Abraham Lincoln paused during the Civil War to set aside the Mariposa Grove and Yosemite Valley as a protected state reserve "for public use, resort, and recreation." Yosemite National Park was then established in 1890 and this grove incorporated into the park in 1906. Today, we value the quiet majesty of these giant sequoias and share a responsibility as park stewards to limit our impact on them.
raw_body_text: Restore and Protect In 1864 Abraham Lincoln paused during the Civil War to set aside the Mariposa Grove and Yosemite Valley as a protected state reserve "for public use, resort, and recreation." Yosemite National Park was then established in 1890 and this grove incorporated into the park in 1906. Today, we value the quiet majesty of these giant sequoias and share a responsibility as park stewards to limit our impact on them.

name: Big Trees Loop - The Fallen Monarch
description: This loop trail features the Fallen Monarch, a massive fallen sequoia where visitors can observe the tree's expansive and intricate root system.

images.title: Big Trees - The Fallen Monarch (Stop 9)
images.altText: Dead and fallen sequoia named Fallen Monarch with roots visible in the air
images.caption: Big Trees Loop - The Fallen Monarch (Stop 9)

raw_listing_description: No one knows how old this tree is or when it fell. Notice the roots of this tree.
raw_body_text: The Fallen Monarch No one knows how old this tree is or when it fell. Notice the roots of this tree.

name: Big Trees Loop - The Wonder of Sequoias
description: This loop trail leads through a grove of Giant Sequoias, allowing hikers to stand among some of the world's most massive living organisms.

images.title: Big Trees - Wonder of Sequoias (Stop 1)
images.altText: Fence lined path in grove with sequoia trees in view
images.caption: Big Trees Loop - The Wonder of Sequoias (Stop 1)

raw_listing_description: You are standing in the midst of one of Yosemite's natural and cultural treasures-and among the world's most massive living organisms. These trees, Sequoiadendron giganteum, are not the oldest living things.
raw_body_text: The Wonders of Sequoias You are standing in the midst of one of Yosemite's natural and cultural treasures-and among the world's most massive living organisms. These trees, Sequoiadendron giganteum, are not the oldest living things.

name: Big Trees Loop - Water and Wetlands
description: This loop trail explores a grove of giant sequoias and the essential wetlands that provide the massive amounts of water these trees require.

images.title: Big Trees - Water and Wetlands (Stop 4)
images.altText: Wayside exhibit on a fence with view of forest
images.caption: Big Trees Loop - Water and Wetlands (Stop 4)

raw_listing_description: Most of these giant sequoias consume a lot of water. Where does the water come from?
raw_body_text: Water and Wetlands Most of these giant sequoias consume a lot of water. Where does the water come from?

name: Big Trees Loop - Wildlife in the Grove
description: The Big Trees Loop winds through the Mariposa Grove, providing hikers a chance to observe dozens of mammal and bird species living among the giant sequoias.

images.title: Big Trees - Wildlife (Stop 11)
images.altText: Tactile statue of a pacific fisher on a granite stone
images.caption: Big Trees Loop - Wildlife in the Grove (Stop 11)

raw_listing_description: The Mariposa Grove provides a protected home for 35 species of mammals and 35 species of birds. Serious threats to Yosemite's wildlife and the ecosystems they occupy include loss of a natural fire regime, non-native species, air pollution, habitat fragmentation, and climate change.
raw_body_text: Wildlife in the Grove The Mariposa Grove provides a protected home for 32 species of mammals and 32 species of birds. Serious threats to Yosemite's wildlife and the ecosystems they occupy include loss of a natural fire regime, non-native species, air pollution, habitat fragmentation, and climate change.

name: Bridalveil Fall Trailhead
description: Take a short walk to the base of the windswept Bridalveil Fall to experience an up-close view of the 620-foot plunging waterfall framed by Leaning Tower and Cathedral Rocks.

images.title: Bridalveil Fall Trailhead
images.altText: A paved path leads through a treed area lined with wood barrier fencing and boulders
images.caption: Bridalveil Fall Trailhead

raw_listing_description: A short walk will lead you to the base of Bridalveil Fall, allowing you to get an up close view of this often-windswept waterfall. Plunging 620 feet (189 meters), Bridalveil Fall is the first major waterfall you'll see when entering Yosemite Valley.
raw_body_text: Plunging 620 feet (189 meters), Bridalveil Fall is the first major waterfall seen when entering Yosemite Valley. Known as “Pohono” to Southern Sierra Miwuk Indians, the waterfall is framed by Leaning Tower and Cathedral Rocks.

name: Cathedral Lakes Trailhead
description: This trail climbs steadily to the shimmering Cathedral Lakes, offering hikers breathtaking views of Cathedral Peak and Echo Peak.

images.title: Cathedral Lakes Trailhead
images.altText: Image of lake from a higher vantage point
images.caption: Upper Cathedral Lake

raw_listing_description: The shimmering waters of Cathedral Lakes rest below Cathedral Peak, named by the California Geological Survey (CGS) in 1863. The trail climbs steadily to Upper Cathedral Lake.
raw_body_text: Cathedral Lakes are nestled at the foot of Cathedral Peak. In addition to the lakes themselves, hikers will enjoy views of Cathedral Peak and Echo Peak.

name: Chilnualna Falls Trailhead
description: This strenuous and steep hike features views of Wawona Dome and a waterfall comprised of five large cascades sliding over granite formations.

images.title: Chilnualna Falls Trailhead
images.altText: Chilnualna Falls Trailhead sign
images.caption: Chilnualna Falls Trailhead

raw_listing_description: Chilnualna Falls, pronounced "Chil-noo-al-na," flows all year, with peak flow in May. It is a strenuous hike, but well worth it for its views of the falls and Wawona Dome.
raw_body_text: Chilnualna Falls, pronounced "Chil-noo-al-na," is a steep hike featuring views of the falls and Wawona Dome. The waterfall is comprised of five large cascades sliding through and over large granite formations above the Wawona basin.

name: Cook's Meadow Loop Trailhead
description: Saunter through a large open meadow in the heart of Yosemite Valley while enjoying iconic views of Yosemite Falls, Half Dome, and Sentinel Rock.

images.title: Cook's Meadow Loop Trailhead
images.altText: Ranger and junior rangers during a program in the meadow looking at a log, Yosemite Falls in back.
images.caption: Ranger program in Cook's Meadow

raw_listing_description: Walk through the heart of it all! Enjoy views of Yosemite Falls, Half Dome, Sentinel Rock, and Royal Arches from the center of Yosemite Valley as you saunter through this large open meadow.
raw_body_text: This short, easy walk offers stunning views of Yosemite Falls, Half Dome, and Sentinel Rock as well as a vibrant example of the rich biodiversity in Yosemite's meadows. From Yosemite Village, walk west along the bicycle path toward Lower Yosemite Fall or take the Valleywide Shuttle to the Yosemite Falls shuttle stop.

name: Elizabeth Lake Trailhead
description: This trail climbs steadily to a glacier-carved lake at the base of Unicorn Peak, featuring a one-mile loop around the shimmering water in the heart of the Cathedral Range.

images.title: Elizabeth Lake
images.altText: Clear, shallow lake waters with boulders in the water and granite peaks above
images.caption: Elizabeth Lake

raw_listing_description: Enjoy the shimmering waters of Elizabeth Lake, in the heart of the Cathedral Range.The trail climbs steadily to a glacier-carved lake at the base of Unicorn Peak. The return hike follows the same route.
raw_body_text: The trail climbs steadily to a glacier-carved lake at the base of Unicorn Peak in the heart of the Cathedral Range. A one-mile trail circles the lake.

name: Four Mile Trailhead
description: This steep and challenging climb rewards hikers with panoramic views of Yosemite Falls, El Capitan, and Half Dome as it ascends towards Glacier Point.

images.title: Four Mile Trail
images.altText: Towering cliffs frame a deep valley with vibrant grasses and a blue river on the valley floor
images.caption: View of Sentinel Rock and El Capitan from Four Mile Trail

raw_listing_description: Awe-inspiring views of Yosemite Falls and Yosemite Valley await hikers on this trail to Glacier Point. The Four Mile Trail has no lack of views; El Capitan and the Cathedral Rocks tower to the west, while Yosemite Falls plummets in the north and Half Dome looms eastward.
raw_body_text: The Four Mile Trail features remarkable, panoramic views of Yosemite Falls, El Capitan, Sentinel Rock, Half Dome, and Tenaya Canyon. This steep trail is challenging, all-day hike.

name: Four Mile Trailhead at Glacier Point
description: This steep trail follows a series of switchbacks down the south wall of Yosemite Valley, offering panoramic views of Yosemite Falls, El Capitan, and Half Dome.

images.title: Four Mile Trail (from Glacier Point)
images.altText: Wooden trail sign at a fork of two trails.
images.caption: Four Mile Trail (from Glacier Point)

raw_listing_description: Awe-inspiring views of Yosemite Falls and Yosemite Valley await hikers on the descent down into Yosemite Valley. The Four Mile Trail follows a series of switchbacks down the south wall of Yosemite Valley.
raw_body_text: The Four Mile Trail features remarkable, panoramic views of Yosemite Falls, El Capitan, Sentinel Rock, Half Dome, and Tenaya Canyon. This steep trail is challenging, all-day hike.

name: Gaylor Lakes Trailhead
description: This picturesque high-country hike features a steady climb to a ridge with panoramic views of the high Sierra and beautiful alpine lakes.

images.title: Gaylor Lakes
images.altText: Two large lakes viewed from high above; peaks frame the lakes
images.caption: Gaylor Lakes basin

raw_listing_description: Take in views of beautiful alpine lakes and lofty granite peaks on this picturesque day hike. This hike offers some of the most spectacular high-country views off of Tioga Road.
raw_body_text: This short but steep hike offers spectacular high-country views, wildflowers in the summer, and lake views. From the trailhead, located right next to Tioga Pass, climb steadily to a ridge with views of the high Sierra including Mt.

name: Glen Aulin and Soda Springs Trailhead
description: Hike through scenic meadows and forests to reach Soda Springs, where naturally carbonated cold water bubbles from the ground inside a historic log enclosure.

images.title: Tuolumne River on trail to Glen Aulin
images.altText: A river cascades over a series of short drops on bare granite
images.caption: Tuolumne River on the trail to Glen Aulin

raw_listing_description: Hike through meadow and forest on this scenic trail that leads you to Glen Aulin and beyond. Soda Springs Soda Springs-carbonated, cold water bubbling out of the ground-is protected within a log enclosure.
raw_body_text: Soda Springs This easy hike features expansive views of Tuolumne Meadows as you walk to Soda Springs, a natural source of cold, carbonated water bubbling out of the ground. The spring is protected within a historic log enclosure.

name: Grizzly Giant Trailhead (Accessible)
description: Wind through a forest of giant sequoias to see the Grizzly Giant, the largest sequoia in the park, and the iconic California Tunnel Tree.

images.altText: People walk on a dirt path to a distinct tree that is much larger than surrounding trees.

raw_listing_description: This tour begins at the Grizzly Giant Accessible Parking area. Winding through a forest with many giant sequoias, this trail features the Grizzly Giant, the largest sequoia tree in the park, the California Tunnel Tree, and interpretive panels on the life and ecology of giant sequoias.
raw_body_text: This tour begins at the Grizzly Giant Accessible Parking area. Winding through a forest with many giant sequoias, this trail features the Grizzly Giant, the largest sequoia tree in the park, the California Tunnel Tree, and interpretive panels on the life and ecology of giant sequoias.

name: Harden Lake Trailhead
description: Hike through a scenic pine forest and past small granite domes to reach the boulder-dotted shores of Harden Lake via a historic gravel road following the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River.

images.title: Harden Lake
images.altText: A forested lake dotted surrounded by grasses, downed trees, and boulders
images.caption: Harden Lake

raw_listing_description: Admire the views as you hike through a pine forest and pass by small granite domes before reaching boulder-dotted Harden Lake. Hike along a gravel road-part of the original Tioga Road-that follows the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River for part of the route.
raw_body_text: Hike to a quiet forested lake beginning from the White Wolf area. The hike begins along a gravel road that follows the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River.

name: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead
description: This trailhead provides access to paths leading to Lookout Point and Smith Peak, offering expansive bird's-eye views of the Hetch Hetchy area throughout one of Yosemite's longest hiking seasons.

images.title: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead
images.altText: Wooden trailhead sign with mileages on it
images.caption: Hetch Hetchy Trailhead

raw_listing_description: Get a bird's-eye view of the Hetch Hetchy area from one of two popular hiking destinations, Lookout Point or Smith Peak. Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone.
raw_body_text: Get a bird's-eye view of the Hetch Hetchy area from one of two day hiking destinations, Lookout Point or Smith Peak. Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite.

name: Lembert Dome and Dog Lake Trailhead
description: Hike through a forest to reach Dog Lake before following a spur trail to the summit of Lembert Dome for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks.

images.title: Lembert Dome
images.altText: Bare rock in the foreground with snowy peaks and partly cloudy skies towering behind
images.caption: The summit of Lembert Dome in late fall looking toward the Cathedral Range

raw_listing_description: Beginning from Dog Lake parking, the trail climbs through the forest to Dog Lake, then take a spur to the summit of Lembert Dome. There is no marked trail on the bare rock on Lembert Dome; choose the easiest path to the summit for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks.
raw_body_text: Beginning from the north end of Dog Lake parking, the trail climbs through the forest to Dog Lake, then take a spur to the summit of Lembert Dome. There is no marked trail on the bare rock on Lembert Dome; choose the easiest path to the summit for panoramic views of Tuolumne Meadows and the surrounding peaks.

name: Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead
description: This short walk leads to the base of Yosemite Falls, offering spectacular views of both the upper and lower falls and a chance to feel the mist during peak volume.

images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead
images.altText: Visitors viewing Yosemite Falls from the trailhead with a full waterfall in the background.
images.caption: View of Yosemite Falls from the Lower Yosemite Fall Trailhead

raw_listing_description: Witness the strength of this mighty waterfall by site, sound, and the feel of its mist, when you stand at its base in spring and early summer when the waterfall peaks in volume. The falls are often only a trickle or completely dry by August.
raw_body_text: This short, easy walk rewards visitors with spectacular views of both Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. This paved loop trail offers different vantage points of Yosemite Falls and Yosemite Creek.

name: Lukens Lake Trailhead from Tioga Road
description: This trail winds through a mixed conifer forest and over a saddle to reach a scenic mountain lake surrounded by meadows and vibrant summer wildflowers.

images.title: Lukens Lake
images.altText: A meadow blanketed in grasses and pink wildflowers surrounded by trees
images.caption: Meadow of wildflowers at Lukens Lake

raw_listing_description: Enjoy fishing, swimming, or viewing the wildflower display that often wraps around the lake in the summer. This short trail winds through a mixed conifer forest, then over a saddle and down to a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow.
raw_body_text: This short trail winds through a mixed conifer forest, then over a saddle and down to a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow. Shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers abound, often through July.

name: Lukens Lake Trailhead from White Wolf
description: This trail winds through a mixed conifer forest and crosses the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River to reach a mountain lake surrounded by wildflower-filled meadows.

images.title: Lukens Lake
images.altText: A blue lake surrounded by conifer forest
images.caption: Lukens Lake

raw_listing_description: Enjoy this small mountain lake surround by a meadow full of shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers in the summer. Follow the trail through a mixed conifer forest to Lukens Lake.
raw_body_text: Walk through a mixed conifer forest to Lukens Lake, a small mountain lake surrounded by a meadow full of shooting stars and dozens of other species of wildflowers in the summer. The trail crosses the Middle Fork of the Tuolumne River and is wet and muddy until early August.

name: Lyell Canyon Trailhead
description: Hike along the Tuolumne River and through lodgepole pine forests while enjoying expansive views of meadows, Kuna Crest, and Mount Lyell.

images.title: Lyell Canyon
images.altText: A trail carves through an open, grassy meadow with rolling mountain peaks
images.caption: Lyell Canyon from the John Muir Trail in late summer

raw_listing_description: Let the overwhelming views of Tuolumne Meadows' peaks and meadows compete for your attention as you venture into Lyell Canyon via the John Muir Trail. Begin across the road from Dog Lake parking area.
raw_body_text: Hike along the Tuolumne River and through lodgepole pine forest, plus enjoy expansive views of meadows, Kuna Crest, and Mount Lyell. This trailhead is part of both the John Muir Trail and the Pacific Crest Trail.

name: May Lake Trailhead
description: A short trail through a conifer forest and across granite slabs leads to a stunning alpine lake reflecting picturesque views of Mt. Hoffmann.

images.title: May Lake
images.altText: A blue alpine lake below a granite peak
images.caption: May Lake

raw_listing_description: Spend a day, or a night, at this stunning alpine lake that reflects a picturesque view of Mt. Hoffmann.
raw_body_text: A short trail leads through a conifer forest and across granite slabs to reach May Lake. Enjoy views of Half Dome, Clouds Rest, and surrounding peaks on the way.

name: McGurk Meadow Trailhead
description: Hike through sub-alpine air to reach McGurk Meadow, where you can explore a historic sheepherder's cabin and enjoy seasonal wildflower displays.

images.title: McGurk Meadow
images.altText: Green grassy meadow with blue skies and trees
images.caption: McGurk Meadow

raw_listing_description: Traipse through a meadow of wildflowers (while staying on the trail, of course), and embrace the cool sub-alpine air this remarkable hike has to offer. The trail leads downhill to McGurk Meadow and the site of an old cabin that belonged to sheepherder John McGurk.
raw_body_text: McGurk Meadow The trail leads downhill to McGurk Meadow and the site of an old cabin that belonged to sheepherder John McGurk. During early summer, look for a tremendous show of wildflowers.

name: Merced Grove
description: This secluded trail follows an old road down into Yosemite's smallest grove, where hikers can view approximately 20 mature giant sequoias in a quiet setting.

images.title: Merced Grove
images.altText: Six giant sequoias behind a wood barrier fence clustered together in a forested area
images.caption: Giant sequoias in the Merced Grove

raw_listing_description: Visit Yosemite's quietest stand of giant sequoias at the Merced Grove.The Merced Grove is home to approximately 20 mature giant sequoias, accessible only on foot. This trail follows an old road that curves down into the Merced Grove, the smallest and most secluded of Yosemite's three sequoia groves.
raw_body_text: The Merced Grove is home to approximately 20 mature giant sequoias and is reachable only on foot (there are no giant sequoias visible from the parking area). This trail follows an old road that curves down into the Merced Grove, the smallest and most secluded of Yosemite's three sequoia groves.

name: Mirror Lake Trailhead
description: This hike offers a unique perspective looking up at Half Dome from its base and provides stunning views of Tenaya Canyon, Mount Watkins, and Washington Column.

images.title: Mirror Lake Trailhead
images.altText: Signs and service road at Mirror Lake Trailhead
images.caption: Mirror Lake Trailhead signage and service road to Mirror Lake

raw_listing_description: With a fresh perspective looking up at Half Dome directly from its base, you'll be rewarded with views of Tenaya Canyon, Mount Watkins, Washington Column, and more. While pleasant at any time of year, Mirror Lake is fullest in spring and early summer.
raw_body_text: This hike features views of Half Dome, Tenaya Canyon, Mount Watkins, and Washington Column. While pleasant at any time of year, Mirror Lake typically only has water in spring and early summer.

name: Mist and John Muir Trailhead
description: Climb a 'giant staircase' along the Merced River to experience spectacular views of powerful waterfalls and unique vistas across Yosemite Valley.

images.title: Mist Trail and John Muir Trail Trailhead
images.altText: A full Vernal Fall with hikers along the rock steps of the Mist Trail
images.caption: Mist Trail leading to Vernal Fall

raw_listing_description: Climb along nature's "giant staircase," where you will be rewarded with close-up views of two waterfalls and numerous geologic features (depending on how far you choose to hike). Powerful and turbulent, these two waterfalls will soak you in spring and entice you year-round.
raw_body_text: The very popular John Muir and Mist Trails offer spectacular, up-close views of two large waterfalls, enjoyable scenery along the Merced River, and unique views across Yosemite Valley. About 1 trail mile from the trailhead, beyond the Vernal Fall Footbridge, the Mist Trail and the John Muir Trail diverge.

name: Mono Meadow Trailhead
description: This trail descends steeply to Mono Meadow, a seasonally wet area offering magnificent views of the Clark Range, Mount Starr King, and Half Dome.

images.title: Mono Meadow Trailhead
images.altText: Trail sign in a wooded area
images.caption: Mono Meadow Trailhead

raw_listing_description: Enjoy magnificent views of the Clark Range, Mount Starr King, and Half Dome, from Mono Meadow. The trail descends steeply to Mono Meadow-an area that is very wet throughout the summer.
raw_body_text: Enjoy magnificent views of the Clark Range, Mount Starr King, and Half Dome from this trail. The trail descends steeply to Mono Meadow.

name: Mono Pass Trailhead
description: This historic trans-Sierra trail follows an ancient trade route, climbing gradually through lodgepole pines, wet meadows, and rushing creeks. Hikers can see red mountain heather blooming trailside during the mid-summer months.

images.title: Mono Pass trail
images.altText: An alpine lake in a meadow surrounded by cured, golden vegetation
images.caption: View from Mono Pass in early fall

raw_listing_description: Follow the path of Yosemite's first people, over their trade route to the east. This historic, trans-Sierra trail climbs gently at first from the Mono Pass parking area, through wet meadows and rushing creeks.
raw_body_text: This historic trans-Sierra trail climbs gradually through lodgepole pines and past wet meadows. In mid-summer, look for red mountain heather blooming trailside.

name: Ostrander Lake Trailhead
description: This trail leads through recovering forest and meadows before a steep ascent reveals panoramic views of granite domes and the shimmering Ostrander Lake.

images.title: Ostrander Lake
images.altText: Lake with granite peaks around it.
images.caption: Ostrander Lake

raw_listing_description: Retreat to nature and encounter the beauty and radiance of this glimmering lake.The first half of this hike gently inclines through forest and meadow where you can observe severe scars and regrowth from a 1987 lodgepole pine forest fire. A steep 1,500 foot (450 m) elevation gain opens up to views of granite domes, Mt.
raw_body_text: The first half of this hike gently inclines through forest and meadow where you can observe severe scars and regrowth from a 1987 lodgepole pine forest fire. A steep climb toward the end of the hike opens up to views of granite domes, Mt.

name: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads
description: These trails offer a scenic descent from Glacier Point to the Yosemite Valley floor, passing by Illilouette, Nevada, and Vernal Falls while providing stunning vistas of the park's iconic landmarks.

images.title: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads
images.altText: Wooden and metal signs at the trailhead
images.caption: Panorama and Pohono Trailheads

raw_listing_description: Some of Yosemite's most iconic natural features can be seen and experienced along these trails. Panorama Trail: This longer route to Yosemite Valley brings hikers past Illilouette, Nevada, and Vernal Falls.
raw_body_text: Starting from Glacier Point, both trails offer stunning vistas of Yosemite Valley's iconic landmarks along the descent to the valley floor. There is NO shuttle service available to transport hikers from Yosemite Valley or Tunnel View back to Glacier Point.

name: Poopenaut Valley Trailhead
description: This steep trail descends into Poopenaut Valley, offering hikers vibrant wildflower displays in the spring and access to the Tuolumne River.

images.title: Poopenaut Valley
images.altText: A grassy valley in a granite gorge viewed from high above
images.caption: Poopenaut Valley

raw_listing_description: Enjoy the wildflowers in spring as you hike down to the Tuolumne River in Poopenaut Valley. Poopenaut Valley (strenuous)2.5 miles (4 km) round-trip; 3 to 4 hours1,229 feet (375 m) elevation gainVisit the Hetch Hetchy Entrance to get more information about hikes in this area.
raw_body_text: This short, steep hike down to the Tuolumne River in Poopenaut Valley is a great spot for wildflowers in spring. Be aware that this is a steep hike on the return trip to the parking area.

name: Porcupine Creek Trailhead
description: Wind through mixed-conifer forest and cross Porcupine Creek to reach North Dome, which offers exceptional views of Half Dome and the surrounding Yosemite Valley landscape.

images.title: North Dome panoramic view
images.altText: Panorama of Half Dome and granite gorges below pink sunset skies
images.caption: Panorama of Tenaya Canyon, Clouds Rest, and Half Dome at sunset from North Dome

raw_listing_description: A day hike to North Dome will reward you with exceptional views of the dome of all domes, Half Dome, and the landscape that makes up Yosemite Valley and beyond.Wind through mixed-conifer forest for 0.7 miles (1 km) on a paved path, and cross Porcupine Creek. At each of several trail junctions, follow the signs toward North Dome.
raw_body_text: This longer day hike provides rewarding views of classic Yosemite landmarks. Wind through mixed-conifer forest, crossing Porcupine Creek within the first mile.

name: Pothole Dome Trailhead
description: This short, easy hike offers magnificent views of high Sierra peaks and Tuolumne Meadows as the trail skirts the western edge of the meadow and curves around Pothole Dome.

images.title: Pothole Dome
images.altText: A granite surface in the foreground backdropped by distant rolling granite peaks
images.caption: View from the top of Pothole Dome

raw_listing_description: Gain magnificent views of Tuolumne Meadows' most iconic peaks, domes, and meadows. Pothole Dome Meadow showcases Tuolumne Meadow's most notable natural features.
raw_body_text: Take a short, easy hike to reach magnificent views of high Sierra peaks, meadows, and domes. A trail along the western edge of the meadow curves around to the east side of Pothole Dome.

name: Sentinel Dome and Taft Point Trailhead
description: Traverse open granite terrain to reach the summit of Sentinel Dome for 360-degree park views, or hike to Taft Point for a sheer overlook of Yosemite Valley and El Capitan.

images.title: Sentinel Dome sunset
images.altText: Pink and blue skies over sweeping views of granite cliffs and mountain peaks
images.caption: View from the top of Sentinel Dome at sunset

raw_listing_description: Get a 360-degree view of the park at Sentinel Dome and/or hike to an expanse on the south rim of Yosemite Valley, getting a close view of El Capitan and Yosemite Valley, at Taft Point.
raw_body_text: Sentinel Dome This wide trail leads mostly across open granite with little shade. Scramble up Sentinel Dome's granite slope to enjoy 360-degree views of Yosemite Valley and the high Sierra.

name: Soda Springs and Parsons Memorial Lodge Trailhead
description: Explore the naturally carbonated water of Soda Springs and the historic Parsons Memorial Lodge on this scenic walk through Tuolumne Meadows, featuring views of the Tuolumne River and granite peaks.

images.title: Parsons Lodge & Soda Springs trail
images.altText: A hiker along a gravel path through a meadow with domes in the distance
images.caption: Meadows, domes, and peaks along the trail to Parsons Lodge and Soda Springs

raw_listing_description: Explore the mystery that is Soda Springs and delve into the history of Parsons Lodge on this delightful walk through Tuolumne Meadows. Walk along the gravel road and pass the locked gate (signed Glen Aulin and Soda Springs).
raw_body_text: Explore the natural and cultural history of Tuolumne Meadows as you enjoy views of the Tuolumne River, many species of wildlife, and granite peaks and domes. Soda Springs is a natural source of cold, carbonated water bubbling out of the ground.

name: Sunrise Lakes Trailhead
description: This challenging hike leads to the stunning Sunrise Lakes, which offer picturesque reflections of the surrounding sky and granite peaks.

images.title: Clouds Rest
images.altText: A narrow granite ridgeline extends toward the horizon and many distant peaks
images.caption: Ridgeline near Clouds Rest summit

raw_listing_description: If you're seeking a challenge with a picturesque payoff, Sunrise Lakes won't disappoint. Indeed, a beautiful place to see a sunrise, the lakes at Sunrise reflect the colors in the sky as well as the domed peaks that surround it.
raw_body_text: Sunrise Lakes Indeed, a beautiful place to see sunrise, the lakes at Sunrise reflect the colors in the sky as well as the domed peaks that surround it. A short distance from the lakes, the Sunrise High Sierra Camp faces east for sunrise views.

name: Tuolumne Grove
description: Follow a historic road downhill through sugar pines and white firs to reach a grove of approximately two dozen mature giant sequoias.

images.title: Tuolumne Grove
images.altText: Two very large trees behind a wood fence surrounded by vegetation showing fall colors
images.caption: Giant sequoias in the Tuolumne Grove

raw_listing_description: Marvel at nearly two dozen mature giant sequoias in the Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias.Begin at Tuolumne Grove parking lot and follow the Old Big Oak Flat Road-one of the first roads into Yosemite Valley-steeply downhill through sugar pines and white firs. The trail drops 500 feet (150 meters) in one mile.
raw_body_text: The Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias is home to about two dozen mature giant sequoias. Begin at the Tuolumne Grove parking lot and follow the former Big Oak Flat Road (now closed to all vehicles) steeply downhill through sugar pines and white firs.

name: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead
description: This historic trail features a steep climb providing close-up views of Upper Yosemite Fall and panoramic vistas of Half Dome and the Yosemite Valley floor.

images.title: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead
images.altText: Wooden sign at trailhead
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall Trailhead

raw_listing_description: A steep climb is well rewarded with close-up views of Upper Yosemite Fall and distant views of Half Dome and other Sierra peaks. Along the hike, enjoy a bird's eye view of Yosemite Valley's meadows and the meandering Merced River.
raw_body_text: One of Yosemite's oldest historic trails, built 1873 to 1877, the Yosemite Falls Trail leads to the top of the waterfall, which cascades 2,425 feet (739 m) above the Valley floor. This trail starts near Camp 4, along the Valley Loop Trail, and immediately climbs a series of switchbacks through oak woodland.

name: Wapama and Rancheria Falls Trailhead
description: Hetch Hetchy's low elevation provides one of Yosemite's longest hiking seasons, featuring diverse wildlife and vibrant wildflowers along trails to scenic waterfalls.

images.title: Trailhead at Hetch Hetchy Reservoir
images.altText: A vast blue reservoir surrounded by granite peaks
images.caption: The trail to Wapama and Rancheria Falls begins at O'Shaughnessy Dam

raw_listing_description: Hetch Hetchy is home to a diverse array of plants and animals, and in spring and early summer, home to brightly colored wildflowers. Enjoy a day hike or overnight backpacking trip (wilderness permit required) in this area at any time throughout the year.Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides for one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite, and the varied trails include something for everyone.
raw_body_text: Hetch Hetchy is home to a diverse array of plants and animals all times of year and is a great area for wildflowers in spring and early summer. Hetch Hetchy's relatively low elevation provides one of the longest hiking seasons in Yosemite.

name: Wawona Meadow Loop Trailhead
description: This scenic loop offers a relaxing stroll with breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin and opportunities to spot local wildlife and wildflowers along a paved path.

images.altText: A wooden sign at the intersection of a trail and road reads, "Meadow Loop Trail," and has an arrow pointing to the left.

raw_listing_description: Take a relaxing and scenic stroll along a trail that offers breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin and gives the opportunity to see wildlife and wildflowers. Walk on the paved road across the Wawona Golf Course.
raw_body_text: Take a relaxing stroll along a trail that offers breathtaking views of the Wawona Basin. Walk on the paved road across the Wawona Golf Course.

name: Yosemite Creek and Ten Lakes Trailhead
description: Travel off the beaten path to a group of pristine glacial lakes or the incredible views found at the rim of Yosemite Valley.

images.title: Ten Lakes Pass
images.altText: Snowy peaks above conifer forest and dark blue lakes
images.caption: Ten Lakes Basin viewed from Ten Lakes Pass

raw_listing_description: Whether hiking or backpacking, travel off the beaten path to a group of pristine lakes or to the incredible views found at the rim of Yosemite Valley. John Muir once described Ten Lakes as "a glacier basin with ten glassy lakes set all near together like eggs in a nest."
raw_body_text: On the north side of Tioga Road, an unpaved parking lot sits next to the Ten Lakes trailhead. Directly across the street, on the south side of Tioga Road, there is a paved parking area as well as the Yosemite Creek trailhead.
